thread.title: A 73mph hypercoaster, air-conditioned capsules and a 400ft ferris wheel: Take a look at the themepark rides that make Orlando 'wheely' amazing
thread.title_full: A 73mph hypercoaster, air-conditioned capsules and a 400ft ferris wheel: Take a look at the themepark rides that make Orlando 'wheely' amazing | Daily Mail Online

author: Simon
title: A 73mph hypercoaster, air-conditioned capsules and a 400ft ferris wheel: Take a look at the themepark rides that make Orlando 'wheely' amazing
text:
9 shares 2
View
comments
Daredevil high-wire walker Nik Wallenda provided the debut flair, but the Orlando Eye needed little extra in the way of razzamatazz to make it the most eye-catching new attraction in central Florida this year.
The 400ft Eye – a close cousin of its lookalike on the Thames – is the standout feature of the just-opened I-Drive 360 complex in the heart of tourist Orlando, and it is suitably dramatic as it provides views for 50 miles in every direction.
Much of the Sunshine State is flat and swampy, but there is enough to see that a ride on the Eye is definitely an eye-opener.
The eye is the stand-out feature of the just-opened I-Drive 360 complex and has air-conditioned capsules
Wallenda – a seventh-generation member of the famous Flying Wallendas family – set everything in motion with a typically madcap stunt, walking atop the Eye as it started up.
But the everyday drama will be provided by the views from the 15-passenger air-conditioned capsules that slowly revolve on the gigantic wheel.
 Next Hollywood's biggest stars, the delights of North Korea and... From Rihanna's beloved Caribbean isle to the Beckhams'... The secret to a great holiday in Ibiza? Go in September,... Revealed: One million fewer tourists visiting Tunisia... To the south-west, the main icons of Walt Disney World, including Epcot’s signature ‘golfball’, the Tower of Terror and Space Mountain, are clearly visible.
To the north-east are the skyscrapers of downtown Orlando, while the full extent of Universal Orlando is even closer.
To the south-west, Walt Disney World is one of the main icons of Orlando
MAKO'S THE NEW RIDE THAT HAS EXTRA BITE Thrilling: A shark at the new Sealife in Orlando
SeaWorld opens its latest ride, Mako, next summer.
The 200ft-tall hypercoaster will be the tallest, fastest and longest coaster in Orlando, covering a distance of almost a mile and reaching speeds of up to 73mph.
Named after the Mako shark, the world’s fastest, it will have tight turns and sheer drops creating a feeling of weightlessness.
Mako will be the centrepiece of a two-acre plaza with shipwrecks, an underwater grill and educational experiences about this endangered creature.
The best-value ticket to visit SeaWorld, Aquatica and Busch Gardens gives unlimited entry for 14 days and costs from £98 per adult and £94 per child. Visit seaworldparks.co.uk .
On a clear day, the vista extends all the way to the massive Vehicle Assembly Building at Kennedy Space Center.
But that is far from all there is at 20-acre I-Drive 360, which has two other signature attractions from the Merlin Entertainments group, a Skeletons museum, two nightclubs, eight restaurants, four cafes and six boutique shops.
Under the same roof are Madame Tussauds and SeaLife Orlando, two attractions that have been given a Floridian twist with interactive elements and local style, with the inclusion of a Walt Disney tableau in Madame Tussauds and an Everglades section in the aquarium. Both are also family-friendly, with plenty to engage all ages.
All three add up to a good half-day of excitement – more if you add on Skeletons: Animals Unveiled, a look at 400 animals as bare-bones exhibits, displayed in active dioramas.
Ready to eat? The restaurant choice runs from Ben & Jerry’s ice cream to the Outback Steakhouse, sushi at Naru and Spanish style at Tapa Toro, as well as the pub vibe of The Yard House.
Want more? Try Cowgirls Rockbar, where you can party into the small hours and ride Orlando’s only mechanical bull, while Tin Roof keeps the party going with live music all week.
It all adds up to a fabulous new array of fun at I-Drive 360 – or you could just call it wheely great.
TRAVEL FACTS Virgin Atlantic ( virgin-atlantic.com ) offers return flights from Gatwick to Orlando from £669pp.
For accommodation, visit legolandhotel.com . Family rooms start at £138 per night including breakfast.
Attraction Tickets Direct ( attraction-tickets-direct.co.uk , 0800 086 1135) offers an I-Drive 360 three attractions ticket with entry to the Orlando Eye, Madame Tussauds and SeaLife from £30 per adult and £24 per child.
